summary:

detailed_news: The International Space Station (ISS) recently welcomed three spacecraft that delivered much-needed cargo. Progress, Cargo Dragon, and Cygnus spacecraft continue to fly vital missions to keep humanity’s presence in low-Earth orbit going. Japan is also readying its HTV-X cargo spacecraft for its first flight this month. Sierra Space's Dream Chaser, however, is no longer targeted to fly to ISS on its first demonstration mission. The Cygnus XL S.S. launched atop a Falcon 9 from SLC-40 at CCSFS on Sept. 14. This was the first flight of the CygnUS XL version of Northrop Grumman’s cargo spacecraft, featuring an eight-meter-long cargo module. NG-23 carried 5,000 kg of cargo to the Station, including a variety of experiments, as well as the usual selection of hardware and consumables. The HTV-X spacecraft is scheduled to fly on Oct. 20 atop a H3-24L rocket from the Tanegashima Space Center. The spacecraft offers the ability to carry large items of unpressurized cargo that other cargo ships would not be able to fly to the Station. The next launch to the ISS will be the Soyuz MS-28 crewed mission, which is currently set for Nov. 27.  NASASpaceflight.com will take part in the 25th anniversary of NASA's space shuttle program. The program will take place over the course of the next 15 years, starting in 2025 and ending in 2025. NASA will be taking part in a number of events during that time, including a spacewalk.

title: Dancing dust devils trace raging winds on Mars
summary: From the ESA Blogs.
detailed_news: Study was led by Valentin Bickel from the University of Bern in Switzerland. Their catalogue is the first ever to include the speeds and directions of motions for dust devils all over Mars. By tracking how fast the dust devils moved, the researchers found wind speeds of up to 44 m/s. This is faster than we’ve ever measured with rovers on the ground – though it’s worth noting that the martian air is so thin that a human would barely even notice a wind of 100 km/h on Mars. Until now, our models of Mars’s climate have been based on the limited data we have from missions that don’t really cover much of the surface. Thanks to this study, we now have lots of new measurements from all over Mars. This improves our understanding and predictions of wind patterns around the Red Planet.

title: Blue Origin transports New Glenn booster to launch site ahead of Mars-bound mission
summary: The booster named ‘Never Tell Me the Odds’ will support the launch of NASA’s EscaPADE mission, sending two washing machine-sized satellites on their way to Mars.

A specific date for that hasn’t been announced, but it's likely in early November. Blue Origin scrubbed the planned launch Tuesday of the company’s suborbital New Shepard booster from West Texas due to a “ground infrastructure issue,” and later said the flight would be pushed back to early 2019. title: Satellites reveal the power of ocean swell
summary: During recent storms, satellites recorded ocean waves averaging nearly 20 metres high – as tall as the Arc de Triomphe in Paris and the largest ever measured from space. Moreover, satellite data now reveal that ocean swells act as storm ‘messengers’: even though a storm may never make landfall, its swell can travel vast distances and bring destructive energy to distant coastlines.
detailed_news: During recent storms, satellites recorded ocean waves averaging nearly 20 metres high. This is as tall as the Arc de Triomphe in Paris and the largest ever measured from space. Satellite data now reveal that ocean swells act as storm ‘messengers’. Even though a storm may never make landfall, its swell can travel vast distances and bring destructive energy to distant coastlines. Long swells carry less energy than assumed, while more energy concentrates in the dominant peak waves. This range of wavelengths has been applied to data collected by ESA-developed satellites. Although these waves remain destructive, their true energy dynamics are now better understood. It's like a boxer who, instead of throwing many weak punches, concentrates their power in a few powerful ones.

title: Sabca Secures €85 Million Ariane 6 Operational Phase Contract
summary:
ArianeGroup has awarded an €85 million contract to Belgian aerospace and defence company Sabca for the production of Thrust Vector Control (TVC) systems for 27 Ariane 6 rockets. Sabca and ArianeGroup signed an initial contract for the production of the first batch of Ariane 6 TVC systems in July 2020. The TVC systems allow both […]
The post Sabca Secures €85 Million Ariane 6 Operational Phase Contract appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: ArianeGroup has awarded an €85 million contract to Belgian aerospace and defence company Sabca for the production of Thrust Vector Control (TVC) systems for 27 Ariane 6 rockets. The TVC systems allow both the Vulcain 2.1 core-stage and the Vinci upper-stage engine to be steered, providing precise control of the rocket’s trajectory and ensuring stability throughout powered flight.

title: Sentinel-1D preparations underway in Kourou
summary: The Copernicus Sentinel-1 mission is about to get its fourth satellite. Copernicus Sentinel-1D has now undergone the checks and functional tests prior to its integration with Ariane 6, ready for launch later this year.
detailed_news: Copernicus Sentinel-1D has now undergone the checks and functional tests prior to its integration with Ariane 6, ready for launch later this year. When it joins its sibling Sentinel- 1C, which was placed in orbit in December 2024, it will significantly enhance the capabilities of the Copernicus Earth observation programme. Having two satellites in operation at any one time is essential for providing timely data.

title: Rehearsing for Sentinel-6B’s early days in space
summary: Last month, mission controllers at ESA's mission control centre started a major simulations exercise to ensure that the next Copernicus Sentinel Earth Observation mission, Sentinel-6B, safely navigates its first days in space. As the launch is approaching, so is the end of this critical pre-launch phase.
detailed_news: Sentinel-6B is Europe's latest sea-level monitoring satellite. It will be launched by a Falcon 9 rocket from the Vandenberg Space Force Base in California. Mission control at ESA’s European Space Operations Centre (ESOC) is getting ready for the launch. The ‘simulation campaign’ is designed to test the mission control team. A final rehearsal of the countdown and launch sequence will take place at ESOC. During the rehearsal, the mission control team will receive live signals from the satellite via an umbilical connection that will be disconnected shortly before launch. Once this final step is complete, the team will be fully ready to launch Sentinel-6B and give it the GO.

title: ESA’s ExoMars and Mars Express observe comet 3I/ATLAS
summary: Between 1 and 7 October, ESA’s ExoMars Trace Gas Orbiter (TGO) and Mars Express spacecraft turned their eyes towards interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS, as it passed close to Mars.
detailed_news: ESA's ExoMars Trace Gas Orbiter (TGO) and Mars Express spacecraft turned their eyes towards interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS. The two Mars orbiters had the closest view of the comet of all ESA spacecraft. During its closest approach to the Red Planet on 3 October, the interstellar interloper was 30 million km away from them. 3I/ATLAS could be the oldest comet ever observed. It may be three billion years older than the Solar System. Next month, we will observe the comet with our Jupiter Icy Moons Explorer. Juice will see the comet just after its closest approach to the Sun. We don't expect to receive data from Juice’s observations until February 2026.

title: Hera’s first year in space
summary: What a difference a year makes! But a year ago, on 7 October 2024, it was unsure if the mission was ever going to take off at all.

title: Laying the foundation for America’s space future
summary:

While the United States and peer nations maintain government-directed space programs, the […]

title: Large Space Simulator gets a digital twin
summary: The Large Space Simulator, Europe’s largest vacuum chamber, routinely reproduces space conditions on Earth to test spacecraft before they fly into orbit. The facility is complex, and the current process of training a new operator is lengthy and complicated. To make it easier, the space simulator now has a digital twin – the most realistic virtual model of the facility yet, developed for the European Space Agency (ESA) by the Spanish engineering company Empresarios Agrupados.

title: Utilize the ISS as a resource: a common sense, fiscally responsible plan leveraging the International Space Station
summary:
NASA plans to spend approximately $1 billion of taxpayer money to destroy the International Space Station (ISS) in 2030. The ISS contains over $1.5 billion worth of space-grade materials already in orbit. Instead of throwing this asset away, we should redirect that funding to develop the technology to recycle it. This approach saves a valuable […]
The post Utilize the ISS as a resource: a common sense, fiscally responsible plan leveraging the International Space Station appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: NASA plans to destroy the International Space Station (ISS) in 2030. The ISS contains over $1.5 billion worth of space-grade materials already in orbit. Instead of throwing this asset away, we should redirect that funding to recycle it. This approach saves a valuable asset, prevents wasteful spending and seeds a new, American-led industry in space. Congress should direct NASA to stop focusing solely on deorbiting the ISS. Instead analyze and fund pathways for utilizing it as an uncrewed demonstration logistics and manufacturing hub. Greg Vialle is the founder of Lunexus Space, a Colorado startup seeking to power the circular economy in space by turning debris into orbital resources. title: ESA inaugurates deep space antenna in Australia
summary: The European Space Agency (ESA) has expanded its capability to communicate with scientific, exploration and space safety missions across our Solar System with the inauguration of a new 35-m diameter deep space antenna – the fourth for Estrack, ESA’s deep space tracking network.
detailed_news: New 35-m diameter deep space antenna is the fourth for Estrack, ESA’s deep space tracking network. Located in New Norcia, about 115 km north of Perth, Western Australia, the ‘New Norcia 3’ antenna will help meet the agency's fast-increasing data download needs and secure Europe's independence and leadership in space. The new antenna has an estimated construction cost of EUR 62.3 million. Construction was led by European industry, with Thales Alenia Space (France) and Schwartz Hautmont Construcciones Metálicas (Spain) as co-prime contractors. Once the new addition is made operational, New Norcia will become ESA’s first ground station equipped with two deep space antennas.

title: SpaceForest Aims to Capture 70% of European Demand for Suborbital Flights
summary:
Polish rocket builder SpaceForest has set an ambitious goal of capturing up to 70% of the European demand for suborbital flights. SpaceForest conducted the first two flights of its 11.5-metre-tall suborbital PERUN rocket in 2023, both of which were aborted mid-flight after encountering anomalies. In October 2024, the company received €2.4 million in co-funding from […]
The post SpaceForest Aims to Capture 70% of European Demand for Suborbital Flights appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: Polish rocket builder SpaceForest has set an ambitious goal of capturing up to 70% of the European demand for suborbital flights. The company conducted the first two flights of its 11.5-metre-tall PERUN rocket in 2023, both of which were aborted mid-flight after encountering anomalies. If successful, the company will look to complete a second flight in 2025, this one reaching an altitude of 80 kilometres. title: Shutdown Continues With No Immediate End in Sight
summary: The Senate again failed to pass a Continuing Resolution today to reopen government agencies like NASA that are closed due to a lapse in appropriations. They plan to try again […]
detailed_news: The Senate again failed to pass a Continuing Resolution to reopen government agencies like NASA that are closed due to a lapse in appropriations. House Speaker Mike Johnson decided this afternoon to keep the House out of session next week as a further attempt to force the Senate to agree to the House-passed CR. If the Senate does not agree to his CR, the shutdown cannot end at least until the House returns to approve any changes. The House will meet in pro forma sessions next week as it did this week. Once she is sworn in, there will be 214 Democrats, giving them a slighter edge. Voters in Texas and Tennessee will soon fill two other vacancies. The longest shutdown was 35 days during President Trump’s first term.

title: Gilmour Space plans return to flight next year
summary:
Despite its first orbital launch attempt lasting only a few seconds, Gilmour Space Technologies is satisfied with the attempt and moving ahead to return to the launch pad next year.
The post Gilmour Space plans return to flight next year appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: Gilmour Space Technologies' first orbital launch attempt lasted only a few seconds. The rocket lifted off the pad but drifted away from the pad and fell back to the ground. Video of the launch appeared to show at least one of the four hybrid rocket engines had malfunctioned. The company expects to return Eris to flight next year. title: Peter Beck discusses Neutron development as maiden flight nears
summary:
Rocket Lab’s ambitious push to launch its Neutron medium-lift rocket before the end of the…
The post Peter Beck discusses Neutron development as maiden flight nears appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: Rocket Lab’s ambitious push to launch its Neutron medium-lift rocket before the end of the year is entering the home stretch. CEO Sir Peter Beck tells NSF that his team is “literally sleeping in the factories” to meet the aggressive timeline. The 141-foot-tall reusable launch vehicle has passed several critical milestones in recent months. Neutron's modular first stage splits into a boost section containing engines and pressurization systems. A boost module might fly 20 times before retirement, while an upper module could reach 50-100 flights. Neutron offers three mission profiles: return-to-launch-site (RTLS) for propulsive landings back at Wallops’ Launch Complex 3. Neutron will follow Electron’s flight cadence philosophy: one launch in the first year, three in the second, then five, scaling from there. Rocket Lab won a $24 million Space Force contract to develop the upper stage. A confidential commercial satellite operator has booked two Neutron missions.

title: EchoStar clears key regulatory step for spectrum sale to SpaceX
summary:
EchoStar said Oct. 3 it has met regulatory conditions needed to maintain rights to the global S-band spectrum it is selling to SpaceX in a deal worth more than $17 billion.
The post EchoStar clears key regulatory step for spectrum sale to SpaceX appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: EchoStar says it has met regulatory conditions to maintain rights to global S-band spectrum. The U.S.-based operator said the Lyra-4 satellite launched in June has successfully operated in low Earth orbit for at least 90 days. SpaceX plans to use the spectrum to enable a 20-fold increase in throughput for its direct-to-device (D2D) services. Jason Rainbow writes about satellite telecom, finance and commercial markets for SpaceNews. He has spent more than a decade covering the global space industry as a business journalist. title: The real space war is being fought in cyberspace
summary:
“The cost of admission is relatively cheap in the cyber area,” Scolese said. “So we remain very much concerned about that.”
The post The real space war is being fought in cyberspace appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: Christopher Scolese, director of the agency in charge of U.S. spy satellites, says he's worried about hackers. The worry is justified, and the attack surface is vast. A well-placed digital intrusion could cascade through an entire satellite network. The challenges are magnified by the rapid commercialization of space. War-gaming and red-teaming exercises that simulate cyber intrusions are not luxuries but necessities. The NRO’s decision to shift toward proliferated constellations of smaller satellites is one way to hedge. Redundancy in space is resilience against both kinetic and cyber threats.
